no you're just not understanding

cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_available_frequencies to show the avalible scaled frequencies. cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor to show the current covenor - if it's 'ondemand', chances are that it's just been scaled back due to low load.
I had this problem before and I was advice to install a package and it fixed it
but I can't remember that package
yeaeh it's on ondemand but for some reason it never changes has I do stuff
it stays at 800mhz

If you're on a desktop you can swap to performance (use highest avalibel freq all the time) - google for it, or as root: echo performance > /sys/devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor. I'm sure there's packages to do it, and I'm -almost- sure it'll stay on reboot, but that's how I've done both my boxes.
If you're on a laptop I'd stick with ondemand to save power.

I don't mind it being on scaling just want to make sure it actually scales

Theres a load threshold setting somewhere, if I remember right. (You'd need to swap govenors for all cpu cores, by the way) - googling for "cpu frequency manager ubuntu" gives lots of packages / other ways.
